content.question: <math alttext="I, in amps" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>I</mi><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>A</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="delta V, in volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>V</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="1.5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="13.5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>13.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="24" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>24</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="37.5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>37.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> A variable power supply is connected to identical resistors <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in series as shown in the circuit. The potential difference The potential difference <math alttext="delta V" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> across and the rate of charge flow <math alttext="I" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> through the resistor <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> are recorded in the table. Based on the data, which of the following statements is true?

choices.label: Resistor <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is ohmic and has a resistance of <math alttext="1.5 ohm" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>1.5</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></math>.

Resistor <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is ohmic and has a resistance of <math alttext="7.5 ohms" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>7.5</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></math>.

Resistor <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is nonohmic and appears to increase in resistance as the potential difference across it increases.

Resistor <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is nonohmic and appears to decrease in resistance as the potential difference across it increases.
It is not possible to tell if resistor <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is ohmic or nonohmic from the data.

content.answer: Resistor <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is nonohmic and appears to increase in resistance as the potential difference across it increases.

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
